NC State athletes are winning at the #ParisOlympics. ğŸ‘ One of the most successful academic years in NC State Athletics history is drawing to a close in sparkling fashion â€” specifically shiny gold and silver. At the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris, two former Wolfpack female athletes won medals, bringing the schoolâ€™s haul to three among the record 13 Olympians from the university who have competed at this yearâ€™s Olympics. Swimmer Katharine Berkoff, a five-time NCAA champion and 30-time All-American from Missoula, Montana, won a gold medal as a member of the United Statesâ€™ 4Ã—100 medley relay team, and professional tennis player Diana Shnaider, a native of Russia, won a silver medal in womenâ€™s doubles as part of the Independent Neutral Athletes. ğŸ”— Read more: http://ncst.at/nAul50SVe4P

Rural NC State scholars are taking North Carolinaâ€™s livestock veterinarian shortage by the horns. ğŸ©ºğŸ„ A new North Carolina State University- College of Veterinary Medicine program is pairing vet students with livestock veterinarians in rural areas of the state to build studentsâ€™ skills, create connections and address a statewide care deficit. â€œAt the vet school, youâ€™re one of 120,â€ remarks Dr. Richard Kirkman, a member of the collegeâ€™s Class of 1991. â€œOut here, youâ€™re one of one.â€ ğŸ”— See how the inaugural program is giving students hands-on experience: http://ncst.at/IfNt50SPJTL

This year's Olympics bill is at least $8.7 billion for #Paris2024. Does the payoff justify the investment? The International Olympic Committee claims the event creates jobs and boosts tourism and leaves behind facilities that provide lasting benefits to the community. It cites cost-benefit studies showing that the games are a net economic benefit to the host city. The truth is more complicated. NC State Poole College of Management economist Steve Allen explains. ğŸ…â¬‡ï¸ #ThinkAndDo
